Washington Schoolboy Athletes Have
Little Difficulty in the Fourth Hopkins Interscholastic Games.

Mount St. Joseph's College fell
an easy victim to the 'Varsity ball
team on Wednesday. The score
was 7 to 1. Hopkins hit the ball
far and frequently, while the Irvington squad seemed unable to connect
with any degree of regularity.
Burns, who was on the mound for
the visitors, was in hot water during the greater part of the time, being particularly unfortunate in the
fourth inning, when a triple, two
singles, two passes, an out, a double
and a steal home brought in five
tallies and put the game on ice. The
bright stars were Webster, who
made a couple of sensational
catches, and Worthington, who, besides fielding everything that came
in his territory, made two long hits.
Rice drew four bases on balls.
As St. Joseph's defeated Maryland Agricultural College, the Hopkins claim on the State title looks
good, and will be clear in case of a
victory over St. John's. The score:

Taking four first, six second and
five third places, Central High
School of Washington piled up
forty - two points and won the
fourth annual interscholastic track
and field meet held under the auspices of the Hopkins track team on
Saturday at Homewood Field.
Episcopal High School of Alexandria, Va., landed second place,
with twenty-six points, and Polytechnic was third, with only five
points less than the Virginians.
There were comparatively few
en..rants from local schools and the
majority of the contestants came
over from Washington. However,
many thrills were offered the spectators, especially during the afternoon's racing — the heats having
been run off in the morning.
The finish of the mile run was
probably the most interesting. Galloway of Central High School
lagged behind until the last lap and
then made a beautiful spurt, finishing barely two feet ahead of Taylor
of City College.
Arthur B. Kinsolving of Episcopal High School, the star performer
of last year's meet, was the largest
individual point-winner.
George Bauernschmidt of Gilman
School, and Bangs of Polytechnic,
were the two local performers with
the largest number of points. The

Crippled by the loss of Dick Sylvester, the baseball team lost to
Swarthmore on Saturday, 3 to 7.
The 'Varsity seemed to go to pieces
without Sylvester in the box, six
errors being recorded — all made
when they meant runs.
Frank Worthington was the one
bright spot in the poorly-played
game—hitting out two triples and
a home run for a total of ten bases.
He also accepted all his chances in
the field.
The pitching of Turning for
Swarthmore was steady and he received good support. Triesler for
Hopkins did creditable work, but in
the pinches he lost his grip. The
team was additionally crippled by
the absence of Webster. The score:

A suggestion is made in the current Revue Bleue for the purpose
of bringing the chronological system into line with the decimalization
of money, weights and distance.
The new proposal involves the
division of the day into twentyperiods, called hores, instead of
twenty-four hours, each hore being
similarly divided into fifty periods,
called chrones, each chrone—about
one and a half minutes—being the
thousandth part of a day, as the
gram and the metre are the thousandth part, respectively, of the kilo0-ram and kilometer. The chrones
are further sub-divided into centichrones, the equivalent of a second.
The deviser of the plan asserts
that the new system would facilitate marine observations, besides
simplifying calculations of time
generally. The French government, however, shows no inclination
to adopt this idea.
A Mere Trifle.

President Hazard of Wellesley
told the following at a banquet:
-A girl graduate, in taking leave
of her dean, said 'Good-bye, Professor, I shall not forget you. I
am indebted to you for all I know.'
"'Oh, I beg of you,' replied the
professor, •'don't mention such a
trifle.'"
He—Don't you think Hahvard
has changed an awful lot in the
last few years?
She—Yes, but not. enough.— Yale
Record,
ludes were emphasized by the lecturer. It was the characters, the
pilgrims to the shrine of St. Thomas, and not Chaucer, who were telling the tales. Every tale in the collection is worthy of its place only
in so far as it throws light on the
character and personality of the
man who tells it. The frank miller, the loud somnour, the meek
prioress, the worthy knight, the
five-times-mated wife of Bath, the
unsurpassable Harry Bailey,—all
are real figures, who tell their
stories, and do not exist merely to
give Chaucer an excuse to inflict a
composite collection of tales on an
unsuspecting public.
Looking back over the whole
course, we do not hesitate to say
that this Turnbull series has been
an unusually instructive and helpful one. Sometimes, we fear, lecturers have been chosen to speak
on subjects which appeal to but a
select feW; but the large and enthusiastic gatherings which have
listened to the Boston lecturer are
evidence enough of the general appeal which this year's subject makes
and of the approval with which the
lecturer's words were received. Dr.
Kittredge will return to Harvard
with the respect and admiration of
many here in Baltimore.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 11, 1914.
Track and Field Records.

Lacrosse.

The local lacrosse season was
brought to a close on Saturday,
when the 'Varsity downed Swarthmore on Homewood Field. One
more game remains on the schedule,
but that is at Cambridge with Harvard. Hopkins has already won a
decisive victory over the Crimson
twelve, and if it simply maintains
form and condition there is every
reason to believe that the season
will wind up in a blaze of glory.
It is particularly pleasing to the
student body and alumni when a
lacrosse twelve goes through its season with success, for the sport constitutes one of the most efficient
means of spreading Hopkins' influence. The game advertises the
University and gives it a certain
form of prestige, just as a major
league baseball team does a city
A novelty firm has recently issued
a series of posters depicting the
various colleges in sports in which
they excel. Harvard is represented
by a football player presumably
Making a sensational end run, for
he has a determined "grit-teeth" expression on his face and is tearing
up the sod; Yale is a baseball
player; Columbia is a sturdy oarsman; and Princeton a track man.
In this series, too, a graceful lacrosse player is shown reaching
high into the air for a difficult pass.
That player has Hopkins spelt out in
black letters on his blue jersey.
It is silly, perhaps, to fell pride
in being brought before the public
on a poster, but underlying the incident it is seen that Hopkins is recognized nationally as the chief exponent of that particular sport, and
this is highly gratifying. If the fact
is brought out on a poster, it has
been impressed on the minds of a
number of people, and that is what
we want.
And it is just such spirit as has
been shown by this year's lacrosse
men that has forged Hopkins to the
front in the game. They have
worked faithfully together, have
played a clean game, have been persistent and scrappy, when necessary,
and have redounded credit to the
University as an institution.
Cornell, Pennsylvania, Harvard.
Swarthmore and the Carlisle Indians, all of them, excepting perhaps Carlisle, institutions having
larger student bodies than Hopkins,
have been defeated. Navy and Lehigh, the two teams played abroad,
won from the 'Varsity, but the\
were breaks in luck, and the Hopkins followers feel sure that return
games would reverse the outcome.
Such a record is an enviable one,
and calls forth for the men who
helped make it — players, coaches
and managers—the congratulations
and commendation of the whole instiution.
— —

It would be an excellent plan if
the track team management would
print on the programs for the meets
at Homewood the records which
have been established in the various
events in previous years.
As it is now, spectators are
obliged to depend on the announcers
to learn of broken records, and frequently, as the marks are not immediately available, a worthy feat
of a victor goes by unheralded.
There would be three-fold advantage in having the record marks
printed on the official program. In
the first place, the program would
be more valuable, inasmuch as it
would give more for the money than
it does at present; secondly, every
spectator would be able to tell for
himself as soon as a time, distance
or height has been announced
whether a new mark has been set
in the event; thirdly, even if the
performance of an athlete was not
record-breaking, it would be interesting for the onlookers to compare
the mark made in the event with the
record mark.
There is nothing original in having the records printed on the programs. It is done at a majority of
the large colleges, and the spectators at the games, undoubtedly,
would deem it a great loss if deprived of the handy information. If
our track management would follow
"Come On In, T he Water's Fine!"
suit and have the records printed
on the programs for the Virginia

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 11, 1914.

UNIVERSITY NOTES

AT OTHER COLLEGES

1916 Hullabaloo Already!

Mysterious Mr.Smiths at M. I. T.

The first meeting of the 1916
Hullabaloo Board was held on
Thursday afternoon for the purpose
of electing officers and deciding
upon plans of action. The officers
chosen were: Thomas J. Tingley,
editor-in-chief, and Myron E. Bagley, business manager. The Board
decided to postpone the election of
an art editor until the beginning
of next year, in order that candidates may have more leisure in
which to prepare drawings. The
financial question was also discussed
and plans for holding benefits were
considered.

Two new gifts to the M assachusetts Institute of Technology from
anonymous donors, who have come
to be known among "Tech" men as
"Mysterious Mr. Smiths," have
been announced. One is $500,000
for use on. new "Tech" buildings,
and the other is $100,00o for use
without restriction. With gifts previously announced, the total now
received from anonymous sources
is $3,150,000. The first gift with
which the name of "Mr. Smith"
was associated was $2,500,000 for
new buildings. The second "Mr.
Smith" gave $50,000 for a permanent summer camp.—Harvard Illustrated.

Poly Defeats Hopkins Scrubs.

The lacrosse team of the Polytechnic Institute succeeded in, defeating the Hopkins scrubs in a
closely-contested game on last Monday by the score of 5 to 2. Captain Wright starred for the visitors,
while Stuart and Kaiser played well
for the scrubs. Ted Prince led the
Hopkins attack by scoring both
points for the losers.
The Polytechnic defense w a s
weak, and their victory was entirely
due to a fast attack. The Hopkins
men, on the contrary, were stronger
in the backfield. Only four shots
were made at the Polytechnic goal.
and two of these resulted in tallies.
The game was particularly interesting because it offered an opportunity for comparing the relative
strength of the City College and
Poly teams by their respective
scores against the scrubs this season. The decision could only be
favorable to the collegians, whose
excellent teamwork enabled them to
roll up a larger score against a
stronger opposition.
Interne at "Pen."

Dr. W. Clark Thomas, a graduate
of the Medical School, was appointed during the past week by John
P. Leonard, warden of the State
Penitentiary, to succeed Dr. F. P.
Carroll as an interne in the hospital
of the institution.

Geologists Are Busy.

An engineer supervising construction on the Falls road tracks of the
Maryland and Pennsylvania Railroad notified one of the local newspapers on Monday that the army
of -Gen." Jacob S. Coxey, which
is tramping to Washington fourteen strong, had been seen in the
vicinity of Schwind's quarry. Investigation proved that the "army"
was a group of Hopkins geological
students.

Grotius Society Again.

The Grotius Society will meet
for its final deliberation of the year
on Tuesday, at one o'clock, in the
Donovan Rom. Plans will be discussed in regard to the future of
the Society and officers will be
elected. All members of the Society have been urged to attend this
closing meeting.

of the New Orleans Item, a wellknown and influential newspaper of
the South. He was editor of this
paper about fifteen years ago.

We sometimes pause a moment to
wonder just what sort of impression
we really make on our readers. We
often think that many of the students are perhaps somewhat prejudiced against our issues because
they already know some of our news
at first hand. The only way to obtain an accurate estimate of the
value of our efforts is to ascertain
how our papers appeal to outsiders
—those who are out of Baltimore
or who are not in closer touch with
the University. During the past
week, we were very much gratified
to receive the following unsolicited
communication from a little town
in Central Pennsylvania : "It is
mighty good to get your NEWSLETTERS, which every member of
the family reads and enjoys thorotighly." Thank you!

Modern Sophecles—What is the
difference between life and two
fond lovers?
Diogenes—Give it up.
M. S. — Life is just one darn
thing after another, while they are
two poor things after each other.
Several members of the Hopkins
medical faculty attended the meeting of the National Association for
the Study of Pulmonary Diseases
in Washington on Thursday. Dr.
David I. Macht, instructor in medicine and co-worker with Prof. John
S. Abel in somc.important research
work, opened the session with a
leading paper, entitled "The Effect
of Drugs Upon Pulmonary Action."

Homewood, the seat of the new
University, has been visited (luring the past week by a large number of students interested in the
progress of.building operations.
The "No Admittance Except on
Business- sign, hanging up on one
of the white pillars supporting the
portico entrance to Gilman Hall, is
still in place, so visitors have to be
content with an exterior inspection.
There are but a few details left to
complete the structure. The new
Donovan Room, facing in semicircle from the west end of the
building, is one of the most interesting features. From the windows
future students there will look out
into the botanical gardens, which,
at this time, have an abundance of
spring blossoms. Just beyond the
gardens is a wooded slope giving on
to the Wyman's Park road, and a
view of the granite bridge spanning
the stream is had. The whole effect is decidedly superior to the
view from the present Donovan
Room.
Much headway, too, has been
made on the Engineering Building.
As yet there are no verboten signs
on it, and many persons have
walked up and down its halls. The
large lecture room in the heart of
the building, surrounded on three
sides with courts, is the most impressive feature at present. On
the east side of the building is the
machinery hall, and a large crane
has recently been installed to put
the different machines in place.
The hall is two stories high and as
long as the main building.
The powerhouse is in progress
of construction just southeast of the
Engineering Building. Foundations were laid last week for the
walls and a gaint smokestack. The
building will be near the old entrance lodge to the Wyman estate.
Forward lookers are now beginning to wonder what future classes
will do without a Hyde or a Doc.
Adams nearby. Lunches and chocolate sundaes are economic goods
and will be as much sought in
future generations as in the present. But these details can be solved.
only when the forces of adaptation
get to work, and so next September
we may expect to hear that some
engineering student has located an
icacream parlor a few paces through
the woods in Woodberry.

Mount St. Joseph's College fell
an easy victim to the 'Varsity ball
team on Wednesday. The score
was 7 to 1. Hopkins hit the ball
far and frequently, while the Irvington squad seemed unable to connect
with any degree of regularity.
Burns, who was on the mound for
the visitors, was in hot water during the greater part of the time, being particularly unfortunate in the
fourth inning, when a triple, two
singles, two passes, an out, a double
and a steal home brought in five
tallies and put the game on ice. The
bright stars were Webster, who
made a couple of sensational
catches, and Worthington, who, besides fielding everything that came
in his territory, made two long hits.
Rice drew four bases on balls.
As St. Joseph's defeated Maryland Agricultural College, the Hopkins claim on the State title looks
good, and will be clear in case of a
victory over St. John's. The score:

Taking four first, six second and
five third places, Central High
School of Washington piled up
forty - two points and won the
fourth annual interscholastic track
and field meet held under the auspices of the Hopkins track team on
Saturday at Homewood Field.
Episcopal High School of Alexandria, Va., landed second place,
with twenty-six points, and Polytechnic was third, with only five
points less than the Virginians.
There were comparatively few
en..rants from local schools and the
majority of the contestants came
over from Washington. However,
many thrills were offered the spectators, especially during the afternoon's racing — the heats having
been run off in the morning.
The finish of the mile run was
probably the most interesting. Galloway of Central High School
lagged behind until the last lap and
then made a beautiful spurt, finishing barely two feet ahead of Taylor
of City College.
Arthur B. Kinsolving of Episcopal High School, the star performer
of last year's meet, was the largest
individual point-winner.
George Bauernschmidt of Gilman
School, and Bangs of Polytechnic,
were the two local performers with
the largest number of points. The

A suggestion is made in the current Revue Bleue for the purpose
of bringing the chronological system into line with the decimalization
of money, weights and distance.
The new proposal involves the
division of the day into twentyperiods, called hores, instead of
twenty-four hours, each hore being
similarly divided into fifty periods,
called chrones, each chrone—about
one and a half minutes—being the
thousandth part of a day, as the
gram and the metre are the thousandth part, respectively, of the kilo0-ram and kilometer. The chrones
are further sub-divided into centichrones, the equivalent of a second.
The deviser of the plan asserts
that the new system would facilitate marine observations, besides
simplifying calculations of time
generally. The French government, however, shows no inclination
to adopt this idea.
A Mere Trifle.

President Hazard of Wellesley
told the following at a banquet:
-A girl graduate, in taking leave
of her dean, said 'Good-bye, Professor, I shall not forget you. I
am indebted to you for all I know.'
"'Oh, I beg of you,' replied the
professor, •'don't mention such a
trifle.'"
He—Don't you think Hahvard
has changed an awful lot in the
last few years?
She—Yes, but not. enough.— Yale
Record,
ludes were emphasized by the lecturer. It was the characters, the
pilgrims to the shrine of St. Thomas, and not Chaucer, who were telling the tales. Every tale in the collection is worthy of its place only
in so far as it throws light on the
character and personality of the
man who tells it. The frank miller, the loud somnour, the meek
prioress, the worthy knight, the
five-times-mated wife of Bath, the
unsurpassable Harry Bailey,—all
are real figures, who tell their
stories, and do not exist merely to
give Chaucer an excuse to inflict a
composite collection of tales on an
unsuspecting public.
Looking back over the whole
course, we do not hesitate to say
that this Turnbull series has been
an unusually instructive and helpful one. Sometimes, we fear, lecturers have been chosen to speak
on subjects which appeal to but a
select feW; but the large and enthusiastic gatherings which have
listened to the Boston lecturer are
evidence enough of the general appeal which this year's subject makes
and of the approval with which the
lecturer's words were received. Dr.
Kittredge will return to Harvard
with the respect and admiration of
many here in Baltimore.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 11, 1914.
Track and Field Records.

Lacrosse.

The local lacrosse season was
brought to a close on Saturday,
when the 'Varsity downed Swarthmore on Homewood Field. One
more game remains on the schedule,
but that is at Cambridge with Harvard. Hopkins has already won a
decisive victory over the Crimson
twelve, and if it simply maintains
form and condition there is every
reason to believe that the season
will wind up in a blaze of glory.
It is particularly pleasing to the
student body and alumni when a
lacrosse twelve goes through its season with success, for the sport constitutes one of the most efficient
means of spreading Hopkins' influence. The game advertises the
University and gives it a certain
form of prestige, just as a major
league baseball team does a city
A novelty firm has recently issued
a series of posters depicting the
various colleges in sports in which
they excel. Harvard is represented
by a football player presumably
Making a sensational end run, for
he has a determined "grit-teeth" expression on his face and is tearing
up the sod; Yale is a baseball
player; Columbia is a sturdy oarsman; and Princeton a track man.
In this series, too, a graceful lacrosse player is shown reaching
high into the air for a difficult pass.
That player has Hopkins spelt out in
black letters on his blue jersey.
It is silly, perhaps, to fell pride
in being brought before the public
on a poster, but underlying the incident it is seen that Hopkins is recognized nationally as the chief exponent of that particular sport, and
this is highly gratifying. If the fact
is brought out on a poster, it has
been impressed on the minds of a
number of people, and that is what
we want.
And it is just such spirit as has
been shown by this year's lacrosse
men that has forged Hopkins to the
front in the game. They have
worked faithfully together, have
played a clean game, have been persistent and scrappy, when necessary,
and have redounded credit to the
University as an institution.
Cornell, Pennsylvania, Harvard.
Swarthmore and the Carlisle Indians, all of them, excepting perhaps Carlisle, institutions having
larger student bodies than Hopkins,
have been defeated. Navy and Lehigh, the two teams played abroad,
won from the 'Varsity, but the\
were breaks in luck, and the Hopkins followers feel sure that return
games would reverse the outcome.
Such a record is an enviable one,
and calls forth for the men who
helped make it — players, coaches
and managers—the congratulations
and commendation of the whole instiution.
— —

It would be an excellent plan if
the track team management would
print on the programs for the meets
at Homewood the records which
have been established in the various
events in previous years.
As it is now, spectators are
obliged to depend on the announcers
to learn of broken records, and frequently, as the marks are not immediately available, a worthy feat
of a victor goes by unheralded.
There would be three-fold advantage in having the record marks
printed on the official program. In
the first place, the program would
be more valuable, inasmuch as it
would give more for the money than
it does at present; secondly, every
spectator would be able to tell for
himself as soon as a time, distance
or height has been announced
whether a new mark has been set
in the event; thirdly, even if the
performance of an athlete was not
record-breaking, it would be interesting for the onlookers to compare
the mark made in the event with the
record mark.
There is nothing original in having the records printed on the programs. It is done at a majority of
the large colleges, and the spectators at the games, undoubtedly,
would deem it a great loss if deprived of the handy information. If
our track management would follow
"Come On In, T he Water's Fine!"
suit and have the records printed
on the programs for the Virginia

UNIVERSITY NOTES

AT OTHER COLLEGES

1916 Hullabaloo Already!

Mysterious Mr.Smiths at M. I. T.

The first meeting of the 1916
Hullabaloo Board was held on
Thursday afternoon for the purpose
of electing officers and deciding
upon plans of action. The officers
chosen were: Thomas J. Tingley,
editor-in-chief, and Myron E. Bagley, business manager. The Board
decided to postpone the election of
an art editor until the beginning
of next year, in order that candidates may have more leisure in
which to prepare drawings. The
financial question was also discussed
and plans for holding benefits were
considered.

Two new gifts to the M assachusetts Institute of Technology from
anonymous donors, who have come
to be known among "Tech" men as
"Mysterious Mr. Smiths," have
been announced. One is $500,000
for use on. new "Tech" buildings,
and the other is $100,00o for use
without restriction. With gifts previously announced, the total now
received from anonymous sources
is $3,150,000. The first gift with
which the name of "Mr. Smith"
was associated was $2,500,000 for
new buildings. The second "Mr.
Smith" gave $50,000 for a permanent summer camp.—Harvard Illustrated.

Poly Defeats Hopkins Scrubs.

The lacrosse team of the Polytechnic Institute succeeded in, defeating the Hopkins scrubs in a
closely-contested game on last Monday by the score of 5 to 2. Captain Wright starred for the visitors,
while Stuart and Kaiser played well
for the scrubs. Ted Prince led the
Hopkins attack by scoring both
points for the losers.
The Polytechnic defense w a s
weak, and their victory was entirely
due to a fast attack. The Hopkins
men, on the contrary, were stronger
in the backfield. Only four shots
were made at the Polytechnic goal.
and two of these resulted in tallies.
The game was particularly interesting because it offered an opportunity for comparing the relative
strength of the City College and
Poly teams by their respective
scores against the scrubs this season. The decision could only be
favorable to the collegians, whose
excellent teamwork enabled them to
roll up a larger score against a
stronger opposition.
Interne at "Pen."

Dr. W. Clark Thomas, a graduate
of the Medical School, was appointed during the past week by John
P. Leonard, warden of the State
Penitentiary, to succeed Dr. F. P.
Carroll as an interne in the hospital
of the institution.

BALTIMORE

Geologists Are Busy.

An engineer supervising construction on the Falls road tracks of the
Maryland and Pennsylvania Railroad notified one of the local newspapers on Monday that the army
of -Gen." Jacob S. Coxey, which
is tramping to Washington fourteen strong, had been seen in the
vicinity of Schwind's quarry. Investigation proved that the "army"
was a group of Hopkins geological
students.

Grotius Society Again.

The Grotius Society will meet
for its final deliberation of the year
on Tuesday, at one o'clock, in the
Donovan Rom. Plans will be discussed in regard to the future of
the Society and officers will be
elected. All members of the Society have been urged to attend this
closing meeting.

of the New Orleans Item, a wellknown and influential newspaper of
the South. He was editor of this
paper about fifteen years ago.

communication from a little town

Several members of the Hopkins
medical faculty attended the meeting of the National Association for
the Study of Pulmonary Diseases
in Washington on Thursday. Dr.
David I. Macht, instructor in medicine and co-worker with Prof. John
S. Abel in somc.important research
work, opened the session with a
leading paper, entitled "The Effect
of Drugs Upon Pulmonary Action."

Homewood, the seat of the new
University, has been visited (luring the past week by a large number of students interested in the
progress of.building operations.
The "No Admittance Except on
Business- sign, hanging up on one
of the white pillars supporting the
portico entrance to Gilman Hall, is
still in place, so visitors have to be
content with an exterior inspection.
There are but a few details left to
complete the structure. The new
Donovan Room, facing in semicircle from the west end of the
building, is one of the most interesting features. From the windows
future students there will look out
into the botanical gardens, which,
at this time, have an abundance of
spring blossoms. Just beyond the
gardens is a wooded slope giving on
to the Wyman's Park road, and a
view of the granite bridge spanning
the stream is had. The whole effect is decidedly superior to the
view from the present Donovan
Room.
Much headway, too, has been
made on the Engineering Building.
As yet there are no verboten signs
on it, and many persons have
walked up and down its halls. The
large lecture room in the heart of
the building, surrounded on three
sides with courts, is the most impressive feature at present. On
the east side of the building is the
machinery hall, and a large crane
has recently been installed to put
the different machines in place.
The hall is two stories high and as
long as the main building.
The powerhouse is in progress
of construction just southeast of the
Engineering Building. Foundations were laid last week for the
walls and a gaint smokestack. The
building will be near the old entrance lodge to the Wyman estate.
Forward lookers are now beginning to wonder what future classes
will do without a Hyde or a Doc.
Adams nearby. Lunches and chocolate sundaes are economic goods
and will be as much sought in
future generations as in the present. But these details can be solved.
only when the forces of adaptation
get to work, and so next September
we may expect to hear that some
engineering student has located an
icacream parlor a few paces through
the woods in Woodberry.
